choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the Xeno diagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Chagas disease diagnosis. Reduviid bugs (vector/foreign host) grown in laboratories are permitted to feed on suspicious patients (original host). The feces of the bugs are checked under a microscope for amastigote forms of the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi after 4-5 weeks.
  2. Identification of dengue virus – viruses are inoculated into the mosquitoes . The virus can be demonstrated easily as it multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, Laboratory rats are used as a T. spiralis vector by feeding them pieces of muscle biopsies from suspected patients. The infected lab rats' muscles can be seen to contain T. spiralis larvae.

 

Advantage of xenodiagnosis: helpful in cases where low pathogen count makes direct microscopic diagnosis DIFFICULT.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli: Incorrect: This is not a xenodiagnostic method. It involves testing the virulence of enterotoxigenic E. coli by observing the fluid accumulation in ligated sections of rabbit intestine.

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: Incorrect: This method involves animal inoculation rather than using a vector to diagnose an infection.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: Incorrect: This is a virulence testing method to determine the presence of toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

 

Clinical history is suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Causative organism - Larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of T. solium.

 

Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of brain) is the most common and most serious form of cysticercosis. About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Other clinical features of neurocysticercosis are increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders, aphasia and visual disturbances. It is considered as the second most common cause of intracranial space occupying lesion (lCSOL) after tuberculosis in India.

 

Treatment –

 

  1. For cysticercosis, excision is the best method, wherever possible.
  2. Asymptomatic neurocysticercosis requires no treatment.
  3. For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis, praziquantel in a dose of 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20-30 days and albendazole in a dose of 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.
  4. Corticosteroids may be given along with praziquantel or albendazole to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.
  5. In addition, antiepileptic drugs should be given until the reaction of the brain has subsided.
  6. Operative intervention is indicated for hydrocephalus

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Antiparasitic drugs followed by steroids: The correct sequence is to give steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs.

 

Option C. Steroids before antiepileptics: While steroids are important, antiepileptics are also necessary to control seizures.

 

Option D. Continue antiepileptics: While antiepileptics are part of the treatment, steroids and antiparasitic drugs are also necessary for managing neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that commonly causes meningococcal infections, which can lead to serious conditions such as meningococcemia and meningitis. Patients with a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system, specifically components C5 to C9, are at an increased risk of Neisserial infections. The MAC plays a crucial role in defending against Neisseria species by forming pores in the bacterial cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. Without this complex, individuals are susceptible to recurrent or disseminated Neisserial infections, which manifest with symptoms like rash, fever, and altered sensorium, as seen in this patient. The clinical presentation of rash, fever, and altered sensorium strongly suggests meningococcemia, a severe form of infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause a variety of symptoms, primarily in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with rash, fever, and altered sensorium linked to MAC deficiency.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and other infections, particularly in hospital settings. It does not have a direct correlation with MAC deficiency and does not typically present with disseminated infections characterized by rash, fever, and altered sensorium.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae: While Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and meningitis, it is not specifically associated with MAC deficiency and does not fit the profile of disseminated Neisserial infections seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus viridans

 

The key points that indicate Streptococcus viridans as the causative agent are:

 

1. The patient has infective endocarditis, which is commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans.

 

 

2. The microscopic examination showed gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, which is a characteristic morphology of Streptococcus viridans.

 

3. The image provided also confirms the presence of gram-positive cocci (violet color) arranged in long chains.

 

4. Among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Enterococcus typically appear as diplococci (in pairs) and not in chains, ruling them out.

 

5. Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with rheumatic fever endocarditis rather than infective endocarditis.

 

Gram Positive cocci

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: This beta-hemolytic streptococcus is a common cause of rheumatic fever and pharyngitis but not typically associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This alpha-hemolytic streptococcus appears as gram-positive diplococci (in pairs) and is a common cause of pneumonia but not a typical cause of infective endocarditis.

 

Option D. Enterococcus: These gram-positive cocci also appear in pairs (diplococci) and are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends.

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh coloured when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: This nematode causes strongyloidiasis and is much smaller and thread-like in appearance compared to Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, this parasite is much smaller and thinner than Ascaris lumbricoides and is primarily found in the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is a hookworm that has a different morphology with a characteristic curved anterior end, and it primarily inhabits the small intestine where it attaches to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

 

The above lesion is most likely caused by  Sporothrix schencki (S. schenckii)

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. In its saprophytic stage or when cultured at 25°C, it assumes a filamentous form, composed of hyaline, septate hyphae 1 to 2 μm wide, with conidiogenous cells arising from undifferentiated hyphae forming conidia in groups on small, clustered denticles. These one-celled conidia are tear shaped to clavate and do not yield chains. The S. schenckii colonies never become cottony or floccose.

Infection with the dimorphic soil fungus S schenckii is usually transmitted by the mold form from organic matter through cutaneous inoculation. The mycosis has also been transmitted from animals through bites or scratches.

 

The initial reddish, necrotic, nodular papule of cutaneous sporotrichosis generally appears 1-10 weeks after a penetrating skin injury. The lesion is a suppurating granuloma that consists of histiocytes and giant cells, with neutrophils that accumulate in the center and that are surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

The fungal infection spreads from the initial lesion along lymphatic channels, forming the chain of indolent nodular and ulcerating lesions typical of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other tissues are involved by direct extension and, less often, by hematogenous dissemination. The most common extracutaneous infection sites are in the bones, joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae. Hematogenous dissemination—particularly in immunocompromised hosts—results in widely disseminated cutaneous and visceral infection, including meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen. It may cause pulmonary disease and local lymphadenitis, primarily in the submandibular and submaxillary regions. It is usually a benign, self-limited condition with no systemic symptoms except for mild neck pain.

 

Option C. Eumyectoma or mycetoma also called as Madura foot, is a chronic subcutaneous granulomatous soft-tissue infection. The etiological agent may be fungal (eumycetoma) or bacterial (actinomycetoma) and appears under microscopic examination as hyphae or thin filaments, respectively. The cardinal features of the disease are tumefaction, sinus formation, and presentation of grains or granules in draining exudate.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa is a common cause of chromoblastomycosis. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. The fungus is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, (known as sclerotic bodies) on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Rotavirus exhibit genetic reassortment similar to that of influenza virus.

 

Rotaviruses - Cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. Genome consists of double-stranded RNA with 11 segments. Segmented RNA helps in easy reassortment of the genome.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Adenovirus can be identified by their icosahedral symmetry with and fibers extruding from the vertices. It is a double stranded DNA virus.

 

 

Option C. Ebola viruses are cylindrical/tubular, and contain viral envelope, matrix, and nucleocapsid components. The virus generally appears in a long, filamentous form, but it can also be “U-shaped,” in the shape of a “6” (the “shepherd’s crook” appearance), or even circular. It is non-segmented and contains single stranded RNA.

 

 

Option D. Rabies viruses belong to Rhabdoviridae which are bullet-shaped viruses with unsegmented single-stranded RNA

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rotaviruses have a segmented RNA genome that allows them to undergo genetic reassortment similar to influenza viruses.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy developed severe headache, fever, and altered mental status after swimming in a warm freshwater lake. CSF examination showed motile trophozoites with round nucleus. Identify the causative organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Naegleria fowleri

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation of acute meningoencephalitis following freshwater exposure, along with motile trophozoites in CSF, is characteristic of Primary Amebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri. This free-living amoeba enters through the nasal route during swimming and reaches the brain through the cribriform plate. The trophozoites show rapid directional movement and contain a single round nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Acanthamoeba castellanii: Causes chronic granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE) primarily in immunocompromised hosts, and keratitis in contact lens users. Does not present with acute onset after swimming.

 

Option C) Entamoeba histolytica: Causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Does not invade CNS or cause meningoencephalitis.

 

Option D) Hartmannella vermiformis: A free-living amoeba that rarely causes human disease. Not associated with CNS infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the distinct clinical presentations and epidemiology of free-living amoebae:

  • N. fowleri: Acute PAM after freshwater exposure
  • Acanthamoeba: Chronic GAE in immunocompromised, keratitis in contact lens users
  • Routes of entry and tissue tropism differ among these organisms

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs. of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The rapid onset of gastroenteritis symptoms within 4-6 hours after consuming the sandwiches suggests a preformed toxin in the food. Staphylococcus aureus is known for producing enterotoxins that cause food poisoning with a short incubation period of 2-6 hours. This bacterium can contaminate food through contact with a carrier who handles food without proper hygiene. In this case, the cook is likely the carrier, having contaminated the sandwiches, leading to the outbreak of gastroenteritis among the picnic attendees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, which has a longer incubation period (6-30 days), making it unlikely to cause symptoms so quickly.

 

Option B. Vibrio cholera: This bacterium causes cholera, characterized by severe diarrhea and dehydration, with an incubation period of a few hours to 5 days, but it typically results from contaminated water rather than food prepared by a cook.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which generally has a longer incubation period (2-4 weeks), and it is usually associated with contaminated water or food.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about cutaneous anthrax, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wool Sorter's disease

 

Explanation:

 

Cutaneous anthrax is an infection caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. The infection typically begins as a small papule at the site of spore entry through the skin. This papule then develops into a painless vesicle and subsequently forms a characteristic black necrotic eschar. The term "malignant pustule" is often used to describe the severe appearance of the lesion. Additionally, cutaneous anthrax is sometimes referred to as "Hide Porter's disease" because it was historically common among workers handling hides and skins.

 

Wool Sorter's disease: This term refers to pulmonary anthrax, not cutaneous anthrax. Pulmonary anthrax was historically common among workers inhaling dust from infected wool, hence the name.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant pustule: This term correctly refers to the lesion of cutaneous anthrax, highlighting its severe and threatening appearance before the advent of antibiotics.

 

Option B. Hide Porter's disease: This is another name for cutaneous anthrax, historically common among dock workers handling hides and skins.

 

Option C. Black eschar: This is a hallmark of cutaneous anthrax, describing the coal-black necrotic lesion that forms as the infection progresses.

 

Educational objective:

 

"Wool Sorter's disease" refers to pulmonary anthrax, not cutaneous anthrax.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The given image shows a hydatid cyst in the liver. Large, unilocular/multilocular, well-defined, hypodense cysts. Contains multiple internal “daughter” cysts of lower density than “mother” cyst (exocyst). Curvilinear ring-like calcification of pericyst (wall).

 

Causative organism – Echinococcus granulosus

 

Definitive hosts – Dogs, Intermediate host – Sheep, Accidental intermediate host – Human (end stage host)

 

In the liver, the pressure effect of the cyst can produce symptoms of obstructive jaundice and abdominal pain. With biliary rupture, the classic triad of biliary colic, jaundice, and urticaria is observed. Passage of hydatid membranes in the emesis (hydatid emesia) and passage of membranes in the stools (hydatid enterica) may occur rarely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma japonicum: This parasitic worm causes schistosomiasis, primarily affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: This protozoan parasite causes Chagas disease, which primarily affects the heart and digestive system, not forming cysts in the liver.

 

Option D. Schistosoma mansoni: This parasitic worm also causes schistosomiasis, affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The condition shown in the image, characterized by a hydatid cyst in the liver, is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The cysts contain internal daughter cysts and can lead to symptoms related to the pressure effect on the liver and biliary system.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

choices.text: Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin
Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin
Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy and appears as shown in the microscopic image given below. Which of the following features/tests will be characteristic of the organism? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catalase negative, optochin sensitive

 

This image is a light micrograph of Gram-stained S. pneumoniae (also known as S. pneumococcus), rounded bacteria (cocci) that usually occur in pairs and sometimes short chains. Their blue color indicates they are Gram-positive.

 

Meningitis occurs when bacteria enter the bloodstream and then cross the blood-brain barrier or through direct contact of meninges with the skin or nasal cavity. The most frequent focus of the infection is the nasopharynx colonized by S. pneumoniae that evades the host immune system. During IPD, the bloodstream becomes invaded, and complement and coagulation systems are activated. Inflammatory mediators are released massively, which makes it easier for the bacteria to cross the blood-brain barrier. Inflammation is responsible for all the typical findings of bacterial meningitis, i.e., CSF pleocytosis.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin: This description is not characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Oxidase-negative and catalase-negative bacteria include many streptococci, but inulin fermentation is not a typical test used for identifying S. pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin: This characteristic fits some Neisseria species but not S. pneumoniae. S. pneumoniae ferments glucose and sometimes other carbohydrates but is best identified by its optochin sensitivity and bile solubility.

 

Option C. Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose: This describes certain gram-negative bacteria, such as Neisseria species, which do not fit the description of S. pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of bacterial meningitis, is characterized by being catalase-negative, optochin-sensitive, and gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci. These features help in its identification and differentiation from other bacterial pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following life cycle is given below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E. Histolytica

 

  • The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir.
  • The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcer.
  • The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces.
  • Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission.
  • The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver.
  • The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, has a simple life cycle that involves ingestion of eggs, hatching in the intestine, and laying eggs around the anus. It does not form trophozoites or cysts.

 

Option B. A. duodenal: Ancylostoma duodenale, a hookworm, has a life cycle involving skin penetration by larvae, migration through the bloodstream to the lungs, ascent to the throat, and finally ingestion to the intestine where they mature. It does not have cysts or trophozoites.

 

Option C. B. coli: Balantidium coli is a ciliate protozoan with a life cycle that involves a cyst stage and a trophozoite stage, similar to E. histolytica. However, it is characterized by the presence of cilia and typically associated with pigs as a reservoir.

 

Educational Objective

 

The life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica includes the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst stages, with transmission primarily by the fecal-oral route. The most frequent site of systemic disease caused by E. histolytica is the liver.

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mite

 

Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The primary vector for this disease is not the adult mite but its larval form, known as a chigger. Chiggers are tiny, red larval mites that transmit the bacteria to humans through their bite. The disease is also sometimes referred to as "chigger-borne rickettsiosis" due to this vector relationship.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tick: While ticks are vectors for other rickettsial diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever (caused by Rickettsia rickettsii) and Indian tick typhus (caused by Rickettsia conorii), they are not responsible for transmitting scrub typhus.

 

 

Option B. Louse: Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. They do not transmit scrub typhus.

 

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for endemic typhus caused by Rickettsia typhi. They are not associated with scrub typhus transmission.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickettsial diseases:

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucor

 

Histopathological staining shows broad septate, hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching, which suggests that it is more likely Mucor.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Aspergillus shows aseptate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Talaromyces: Talaromyces is a genus of fungi that forms septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that appears as broad-based budding yeast in tissue sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

Explanation:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is mediated by a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of reaction:

 

  • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies.
  • The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation.
  • Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens).
  • Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation.
  • Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation.
  • Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).

 

Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.

 

Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation.
  • Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition. It presents with tender nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation and is commonly associated with lepromatous leprosy.

choices.text: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus
It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria
It promotes the growth of pseudomonas

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over other media for the culture of organisms in case of UTI because: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It inhibits proteus swarming

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

 

Proteus species are a common cause of UTI and produce swarming on ordinary medias leading to difficult isolation of other important urinary pathogens

 

Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, it changes to yellow in case of acid production during fermentation of lactose or changes to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria build yellow colonies. Bacteria which decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and build deep blue colonies.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus. CLED media does not specifically promote the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus.
 

 

Option C. It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria: This is also true for CLED medium but not the reason why it is specifically used for urinary pathogens. Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, changing to yellow in case of acid production during lactose fermentation or to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria form yellow colonies, while bacteria that decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and form deep blue colonies.

 

Option D. It promotes the growth of Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can grow on CLED medium, it is not specifically promoted by this medium compared to the growth of Candida, Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

choices.text: They are unable to mount inflammation against the virus
Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA
There is a risk of elevation of transaminases
Liver parenchymal cells are in a state of high proliferation

questions.text: There are 3 to 5% healthy hepatitis B carriers in India who are asymptomatic. They are at the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma in the future because? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

 

In most tumors, HBV DNA is integrated into the cell genome, and in most cases, the virus DNA has undergone rearrangements, including deletions. After integration, it promotes the overexpression of cell genes that can also contribute to oncogenesis.

 

The only viral gene product that is consistently present in the tumor cells is the X protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Inability to mount inflammation against the virus is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC.

 

Option C: Elevated transaminases indicate liver inflammation but are not directly related to the integration of viral DNA and oncogenesis.

 

Option D: High proliferation of liver parenchymal cells is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC due to HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus can integrate its DNA into the host genome, leading to genetic mutations and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A patient with prosthetic valve implantation, presented after six months with features of endocarditis. What could be the cause? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. epidermidis

 

Explanation:

 

Endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart, the endocardium, which often involves the heart valves. Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) can be categorized into early-onset and late-onset based on the time of onset after surgery. Early-onset PVE occurs within one year of valve implantation, while late-onset occurs after one year.

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus and is a common cause of early-onset PVE due to its ability to form biofilms on prosthetic materials. Biofilms protect the bacteria from the host immune system and antibiotic treatment, making infections difficult to eradicate.

 

Given that the patient developed endocarditis six months after prosthetic valve implantation, it falls under early-onset PVE. Therefore, the most likely causative organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can cause healthcare-associated infections, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism is a common cause of both native and prosthetic valve endocarditis, particularly in intravenous drug users and hospital-acquired cases. However, for early-onset PVE, Staphylococcus epidermidis is more typical.

 

Option D. S. saprophyticus: This organism is commonly associated with urinary tract infections and is not a typical cause of endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification to diagnose causative organism of Endocarditis -

questions.text: The following image is caused by infection with which virus? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CMV

 

The given image shows owl's eye inclusion bodies (intranuclear basophilic inclusions) which is characteristically seen in CMV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are characterized by koilocytes, which have a perinuclear halo and wrinkled nuclei. They do not show owl's eye inclusion bodies.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) does not produce owl's eye inclusion bodies. HIV is typically diagnosed with serological tests and does not produce specific histopathological features like CMV.

 

Option D. EBV: Incorrect. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections are associated with atypical lymphocytes, also known as Downey cells. They do not produce owl's eye inclusion bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl's eye inclusion bodies, which are intranuclear basophilic inclusions, are characteristic of CMV infection. This feature helps distinguish CMV from other viral infections in histopathological examinations.

questions.text: Which medication is used to treat an infection caused by the cestode egg of the given organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Praziquantel

 

The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5-10 mg/kg once).

 

H. nana egg is colorless, almost transparent, oval, non-bile stained, 30–50 µm (micrometers) in diameter, has polar filaments. When shed in stool they are immediately infective and survive up to 10 days in the external environment, they are embryonated and have a 6-hooked oncospheres inside the shells.

 

Shell consists of two distinct membranes; inner membrane has two small “knobs” or poles from which 4–8 filaments arise and spread.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is used to treat infections caused by various nematodes and ectoparasites but is not effective against cestodes like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option C. Albendazole: Albendazole is an effective treatment for various helminth infections, including some cestodes, but praziquantel is specifically preferred for Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option D. Diethylcarbamazine: Diethylcarbamazine is used primarily for treating filarial infections, not cestode infections like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Educational Objective

 

Praziquantel is the medication used to treat infections caused by the cestode egg of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm). The eggs are colorless, almost transparent, and immediately infective when shed in stool. Praziquantel effectively treats this infection with a single dose of 5-10 mg/kg.

questions.text: A patient presents with episodic swelling and inflammation of eyelids with subconjunctival nodules. Blood smear shows sheathed microfilaria with nuclei extending to the tip of the tail. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Loa loa

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation of eye involvement with subconjunctival nodules, along with sheathed microfilaria having nuclei extending to the tail tip, is characteristic of Loa loa infection (African eye worm). Loa loa microfilariae are sheathed and have nuclei that extend to the tip of the tail, distinguishing them from other filarial worms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Wuchereria bancrofti: Causes lymphatic filariasis with lower limb edema. Its microfilariae are sheathed but lack nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option C) Brugia malayi: Also causes lymphatic filariasis. Its microfilariae are sheathed but have two distinct terminal nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D) Mansonella perstans: Microfilariae are unsheathed and have nuclei extending to the tail tip but don't cause eye manifestations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand distinctive features of different microfilariae:

  • Loa loa: Sheathed, nuclei to tail tip, eye manifestations
  • W. bancrofti: Sheathed, no tail nuclei, lymphatic symptoms
  • B. malayi: Sheathed, two terminal nuclei, lymphatic symptoms
  • M. perstans: Unsheathed, blunt tail with nuclei

questions.text: Outbreak of diarrhea. Rice water stool in nature. Pathogen exhibited darting motility. What is the organism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio cholerae

 

Characteristic features of Vibrio cholera:

 

  • Rice water stool: This is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholerae. The stool looks similar to the water left after washing rice, which is a key indicator of this infection.
  • Darting motility: Vibrio cholerae exhibits a unique form of motility known as darting motility. This type of movement resembles a shooting star, which is rapid and straight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, not characterized by rice water stools or darting motility.

 

Option C. E. coli: While certain strains of E. coli can cause diarrhea, they do not produce rice water stools nor do they exhibit darting motility. Their motility is usually peritrichous flagella-based.

 

Option D. Shigella dysentriae: This pathogen causes dysentery, characterized by bloody diarrhea, not rice water stools. It also does not exhibit darting motility; its movement is typically more sluggish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of motility:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus, it is a yeast like organism that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Dimorphic fungi are fungi that can exist in two different forms depending on the temperature.
  • At 25°C (room temperature), they grow in a mold (mycelial) form.
  • At 37°C (body temperature), they grow in a yeast form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis: A dimorphic fungus causing blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: A dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis.

 

Option D. Penicillium marneffei: A dimorphic fungus causing penicilliosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillium marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Coccidioides posadasii

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain since 4 days with a history of remitting fever and bradycardia after having meals outside frequently. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood culture

 

The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, remitting fever, bradycardia, and a history of eating meals outside suggest a diagnosis of typhoidal salmonella. In the early phase of this infection, particularly within the first week, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a blood culture. Blood cultures are most effective in detecting Salmonella bacteria during the initial week of illness, which aligns with the patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Early detection through blood culture is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test: This test is typically performed in the second week of illness when antibodies against Salmonella begin to rise. Since the patient is only 4 days into the illness, the Widal test is not the most reliable at this stage.

 

Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures may become positive later in the course of typhoid fever, typically in the third or fourth week. It is not useful in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures are generally useful in the later stages of typhoid fever, around the third week. They are not as effective for early detection within the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cases of typhoidal salmonella presenting within the first week of symptoms, a blood culture is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

choices.text: Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic
That the patient is in window period

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV2 in the blood likely indicates? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV 2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection even if the patient has been asymptomatic.

 

1-3 weeks after symptoms onset, SARS CoV2 antibody become detectable. At this time infectiousness is decreased and some amount of immunity from future infection has developed.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Presence of acute viral load: The presence of antibodies does not indicate an acute viral load. Acute infection is usually detected through the presence of viral RNA using PCR tests, not antibodies.

 

Option C. A high risk of reinfection: The presence of antibodies suggests that the individual has some level of immunity, which generally reduces the risk of reinfection rather than increasing it.

 

Option D. That the patient is in window period: The window period refers to the time after initial infection when antibodies are not yet detectable. Therefore, the presence of antibodies indicates that the patient is beyond the window period.

 

Educational objective

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection, which may have been asymptomatic. This serological evidence shows that the person has developed an immune response to the virus.

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false and reason is also true
Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria


Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria    (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.

 

Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.

 

  1. Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  2. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  3. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.

 

Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.

 

Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Oxidase positive Gram-negative bacilli that do not show colored colonies on MacConkey media? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Pseudomonas

 

Explanation:

 

Pseudomonas is an oxidase-positive Gram-negative bacillus that does not produce colored colonies on MacConkey agar because it is a lactose non-fermenter. On MacConkey agar, lactose non-fermenting bacteria produce colorless colonies since they do not ferment lactose to produce acid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Shigella: Shigella is oxidase-negative and does not ferment lactose, producing colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.

 

Option B. Salmonella: Salmonella is oxidase-negative and does not ferment lactose, resulting in colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.

 

Option C. Proteus: Proteus is oxidase-negative and does not ferment lactose, hence it forms colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pseudomonas is an oxidase-positive, lactose non-fermenting Gram-negative bacillus that forms colorless colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with frothy, foul-smelling vaginal discharge and pruritus. Microscopic examination of the discharge shows characteristic motile organisms. Identify the causative organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

Explanation: 

 

The microscopic examination shows motile organisms characteristic of Trichomonas vaginalis. T. vaginalis is a protozoan that causes trichomoniasis, presenting with frothy, malodorous vaginal discharge, vulvar irritation, and pruritus. On wet mount microscopy, the organisms show characteristic jerky motility with flagellar movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Shows non-motile Gram-negative diplococci on microscopy. Usually presents with purulent cervicitis or urethritis.

 

Option C) Gardnerella vaginalis: Associated with bacterial vaginosis, showing "clue cells" on microscopy without motility. The discharge is typically thin, grey, and homogeneous with a fishy odor.

 

Option D) Candida albicans: Shows pseudohyphae and budding yeast cells on microscopy without motility. The discharge is typically thick, white, and cottage cheese-like.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the microscopic characteristics and clinical presentations of different organisms causing vaginal discharge, emphasizing the importance of correlating clinical features with microscopic findings for accurate diagnosis of sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obligate intracellular organism

 

Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is a facultative intracellular organism.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an obligate human pathogen and is the etiological agent of gonorrhea.

 

Habitat –

 

  • Human is only the natural host.
  • Found in human urogenital tract.
  • Rectal carriage in healthy individuals.
  • Typically seen in pus cells (intracellular)
  • Found intracellularly in polymorphonuclear leukocytes, or a specific category of white blood cells with varying shapes of nuclei.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase and oxidase positive: This is true for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which tests positive for both catalase and oxidase enzymes.

 

Option B. Pili is a virulence factor: Neisseria gonorrhoeae has pili on its surface, which are essential for its virulence, aiding in attachment and colonization.

 

Option D. Shows twitching motility: Neisseria gonorrhoeae exhibits twitching motility, a type of bacterial movement.

 

Educational Objective

 

Morphology of Neisseria Gonorrhea -

 

  • Gram –ve cocci
  • Shape is spherical
  • Coffee bean shaped diplococcic
  • Usually seen in pairs with adjacent sides flattened
  • LPS has highly branched basal oligosaccharide structure
  • Contains fimbriae
  • Possess pili on the surface
  • Motile (Twitching motility)
  • Non-capsulated
  • Non-sporing

 

It is catalase and oxidase positive.

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

 

Above CT image shows left renal hydatid cyst. In this case, FNAC or biopsy should not be done before nephrectomy as puncture of the cyst while obtaining cystic fluid may cause escape of hydatid fluid and consequent anaphylaxis. Therefore, fluid aspirated from surgically removed cyst should only be examined.

 

Echinococcus causes hydatid cyst in man. It is segmented and smaller than other cestodes.

 

Most of the times infection is asymptomatic and accidentally discovered.

 

Clinical disease develops only when the hydatid cyst has grown big enough to cause obstructive symptoms. Disease results mainly from pressure effects caused by the enlarging cysts.

 

In about half the cases, the primary hydatid cyst occurs in liver, mostly in the right lobe. Hepatomegaly, pain and obstructive jaundice are the usual manifestations.

 

The next common site is the lung (25%) (most common being the lower lobe of the right lung). Cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, pneumothorax and dyspnea constitute the clinical picture.

 

In the kidney (2%), hydatid cyst causes pain and hematuria.

 

Apart from pressure effects, another pathogenic mechanism in hydatid disease is hypersensitivity to the echinococcal antigen. The host is sensitized to the antigen by minute amounts of hydatid fluid seeping through the capsule. Hypersensitivity may cause urticaria. But if a hydatid cyst ruptures spontaneously or during surgical interference/FNAC, massive release of hydatid fluid may cause severe, even fatal anaphylaxis.

 

CT imaging is diagnostic to visualize daughter cysts within large cysts

 

Treatment

 

Traditionally surgical removal was considered as the best mode of treatment of cysts.

 

Currently, ultrasound staging is recommended and management depends on the stage.

 

In early stages, the treatment of choice is puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR).

 

Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration, considered as a controversial procedure earlier, is now widely used in early stages of the disease. The basic steps involved in PAlR include:

 

  • Ultrasound or CT-guided puncture of the cyst.
  • Aspiration of cyst fluid.
  • Infusion of sporicidal agent (usually 95% ethanol; alternatively, hypertonic saline)
  • Reaspiration of the fluid after 5 minutes.
  • Great care is taken to avoid spillage and cavities are sterilized with 0.5% silver nitrate or 2.7% sodium chloride for prophylaxis of secondary peritoneal echinococcosis due to inadvertent spillage of fluid du ring PAIR.

 

Albendazole (15 mg/ kg in row divided doses) is initiated 4 days before the procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards.

 

Surgery: It is the treatment of choice for complicated E. granulosus cysts like those communicating with the biliary tract and in those cysts where PAIR is not possible.

 

Renal involvement requires surgical treatment, either simple excision of the cyst or partial/total nephrectomy if extensive disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Albendazole can be started preoperatively: This is correct. Albendazole (15 mg/kg in two divided doses) is initiated 4 days before any surgical or puncture procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards to reduce the risk of spillage and subsequent anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option B. Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction: This is correct. The contents of a hydatid cyst contain highly antigenic material, and rupture or spillage of this material can cause a severe anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option C. A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent: This is correct. Echinococcus granulosus, a segmented tapeworm found in dogs, is the causative agent of hydatid disease.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: A child presents with asymptomatic white nodules attached to hair shafts. Microscopy of the hair shows arthroconidia arranged in chains around the hair shaft. Identify the causative organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Trichosporon beigelii

 

Explanation: 

 

The microscopic findings describe white piedra, caused by Trichosporon beigelii. The characteristic feature is the presence of soft, white to light brown nodules composed of arthroconidia arranged in chains around (not within) the hair shaft. This is an ectothrix infection, where fungal elements are found outside the hair shaft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Microsporum canis: Causes ectothrix infection with small spores arranged in a mosaic pattern around the hair shaft, associated with fluorescence under Wood's lamp.

 

Option C) Malassezia furfur: Associated with pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, does not form nodules on hair shafts.

 

Option D) Trichophyton tonsurans: Causes endothrix infection with fungal elements within the hair shaft, not forming external nodules.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand different patterns of fungal hair infections:

  • Ectothrix: Fungal elements outside hair shaft (M. canis, T. beigelii)
  • Endothrix: Fungal elements inside hair shaft (T. tonsurans)
  • Nodular infections: White piedra (T. beigelii) vs Black piedra (Piedraia hortae)

questions.text: The following tzanck smear finding is seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV

 

Given tzanck smear finding is seen in HSV

 

The Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, which are characteristic of HSV infection. This test is commonly used to diagnose herpes infections, including HSV-1 and HSV-2, and can also detect varicella-zoster virus (the cause of chickenpox and shingles).

 

It used to diagnose some skin blistering disorders for ex: Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chicken pox: Incorrect. While Tzanck smears can be used to diagnose varicella-zoster virus infections, the specific question and provided image are more indicative of HSV.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. HIV is not typically diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HIV diagnosis is usually confirmed with blood tests, including ELISA and Western blot.

 

Option D. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is not diagnosed with a Tzanck smear. HPV diagnosis usually involves DNA tests and Pap smears for cervical lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tzanck smears are useful for diagnosing skin infections caused by herpes viruses, including HSV-1 and HSV-2. The presence of multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass chromatin is a hallmark of HSV infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. JC virus: Incorrect, while JC virus can cause infections in transplant recipients, its occurrence is less frequent compared to CMV during this specific post-transplant period.

 

Option C. BK virus: Incorrect, although BK virus is a concern in renal transplant patients, particularly for its role in causing nephropathy, it is not as predominant as CMV in the early months following transplantation.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr virus: Incorrect, Epstein-Barr virus also poses a risk for post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders in transplant recipients, but it is less commonly the primary pathogen within the first few months post-transplant compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:


Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation, showcasing the importance of monitoring and managing CMV to prevent its common presentations and complications in this vulnerable period.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgE

 

Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is specifically associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. In the context of chronic allergies, such as asthma, hay fever, and other allergic conditions, IgE levels are typically elevated. IgE binds to allergens and triggers histamine release from mast cells and basophils, leading to the symptoms of allergic reactions.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily found in mucous membranes, secretions like tears, saliva, and colostrum, and plays a critical role in mucosal immunity.

 

Option B. IgM: IgM is the main antibody of primary immune responses and is effective at fixing complement. It is also found as a monomer on the surface of B cells.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is the most abundant antibody in blood and extracellular fluid, providing the majority of antibody-based immunity against invading pathogens. It is the main antibody involved in secondary immune responses and can cross the placenta.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are suggestive of viral meningitis, most probably caused by an Enterovirus. Enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis and present with fever, rashes, and mild lymphocytosis in the CSF.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. West Nile virus: Although it can cause meningitis, there is no history of travel, making this less likely. West Nile virus is endemic in certain regions of North America like California Central Valley, southwestern Arizona, southern Texas, and Louisiana, which have both compatible climates and avian reservoirs for the disease.

 

Option B. Meningococci: Typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Option C. Strep pneumoniae: Also typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Educational objective

 

CSF Findings for Different Types of Meningitis:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with painless genital ulcer and regional lymphadenopathy 3 weeks after unprotected sexual intercourse. Microscopy shows spirochetes. The best culture medium for isolation of the causative organism is: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Rabbit testicular tissue

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation suggests primary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum. This organism cannot be cultured on artificial media. The only reliable method for maintaining and propagating T. pallidum is through rabbit testicular tissue culture (rabbit infectivity test), which remains the gold standard for maintaining viable organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Thayer Martin agar: This is selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which presents with purulent urethral discharge and dysuria, not with painless ulcers.

 

Option C) MacConkey agar: This medium is used for enteric Gram-negative bacteria and cannot support the growth of fastidious organisms like T. pallidum.

 

Option D) Blood agar: While this is an enriched medium, it cannot support the growth of T. pallidum, which requires living tissue for propagation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand that some pathogenic organisms, particularly T. pallidum, cannot be cultured on artificial media and require specialized living tissue systems for propagation, emphasizing the unique diagnostic challenges in confirming syphilis infection.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that has not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa with consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.

 

Symptoms develop within 15-90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea.
