The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8-12 h.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Salmonella: Incorrect because Salmonella is not typically involved in the histamine production leading to scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus: Incorrect as Staphylococcus does not contribute to histamine production in fish, which is the primary cause of scombroid poisoning.

 

Option D. Peptostreptococcus: Incorrect because Peptostreptococcus is not associated with the decomposition of fish that leads to histamine production and subsequent scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Educational Objective

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin
Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts, suggestive of modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid fast (holding capacity).

 

Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence, they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure.

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain).

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly. Heat is used as mordant (A mordant is a substance that increases the affinity of the cell wall for a stain by binding to the primary stain, thus forming an insoluble complex, which gets trapped in the cell wall). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is not used for modified acid-fast staining but is related to Gram staining.

 

Option C. Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet: This is incorrect as the proper primary stain for the modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain is Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin.

 

Option D. Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is incorrect for modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains → Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

questions.text: A patient came with meningitis. His protein level was elevated and glucose level was normal. CSF examination showed lymphocytosis. What is the likely etiology? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

The key points that indicate Mycobacterium tuberculosis as the likely etiology are:

 

  1. The patient presented with meningitis, which can be classified into three types: bacterial (acute), viral (acute), and chronic (tuberculous).
  2. The CSF examination showed lymphocytosis (elevated lymphocytes), which is characteristic of chronic tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  3. In bacterial meningitis (caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis), neutrophils are typically elevated, not lymphocytes.
  4. The normal CSF has 0-4 lymphocytes per microliter, while in tuberculous meningitis, the lymphocyte count ranges from 100 to 1000 per microliter.
  5. The protein level was elevated, which is seen in all types of meningitis, and the glucose level was normal, which can occur in tuberculous meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae, B. H. influenzae, and C. Neisseria meningitidis: These are bacterial causes of acute meningitis, which typically present with neutrophilic pleocytosis (elevated neutrophils) in the CSF, not lymphocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with meningitis, the presence of lymphocytosis (elevated lymphocytes) in the CSF, along with an elevated protein level and normal glucose level, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10-30 days

 

The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days.

 

The causative agent is Chlamydia trachomatis, serovars L1, L2, L3. Chlamydia is a ubiquitous ovoid or obligate intracellular bacteria.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum primarily affects the lymphatic system. Chlamydia trachomatis serovars extend from the primary infection site to the regional lymph nodes and cause a lymphoproliferative reaction, facilitated by binding of Chlamydia trachomatis to the epithelial cells. Binding occurs via heparin sulfate receptors.

 

The basis for a definitive diagnosis of LGV is on serology tests (complement fixation or micro-immunofluorescence) or identification of Chlamydia trachomatis in genital, rectal and lymph node specimens (by culture, nucleic acid amplification test or direct immunofluorescence).

 

Educational Objective

 

The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is 10-30 days. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, and primarily affects the lymphatic system. Diagnosis is based on serological tests or identification of the bacteria in clinical specimens through various methods.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is a form of cell-mediated immune response that occurs typically 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. This response is primarily mediated by T-helper 1 (Th1) cells which secrete a variety of cytokines, including Interferon gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is crucial in activating macrophages and enhancing their microbicidal activity, which is a key component of the DTH response. This type of hypersensitivity is important in defense against intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) - IL-2 is primarily involved in the activation and proliferation of T cells but is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) - IL-12 plays a role in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and can promote IFN-γ production, but it is not the direct mediator of DTH.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) - IL-4 is associated with the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and promotes humoral immunity, which is not involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA

 

Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to detect specific RNA sequences within a sample. This method involves the separation of RNA by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labeled complementary DNA probe. The technique allows for the identification and analysis of RNA molecules, making it a valuable tool in gene expression studies and diagnostic applications. The name "Northern blotting" was coined as a play on words, referencing the "Southern blot," a technique used for DNA detection developed by Edward M. Southern.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. DNA: This is detected by Southern blotting, not Northern blotting. Southern blotting involves the identification of specific DNA sequences using DNA probes.

 

Option C. Proteins: This is detected by Western blotting. Western blotting uses antibodies to identify specific protein sequences after separation by SDS-PAGE.

 

Educational Objective

 

SNoW - DRoP:-

 

  1. SOUTHERN - DNA
  2. NORTHERN - RNA
  3. WESTERN - Protein

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

Other Options


Option A. Giardia lamblia: The stool examination usually reveals oval-shaped cysts or trophozoites. Giardia does not produce eggs, distinguishing it from helminthic infections.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs are typically oval-shaped and brown-colored. They have a distinct thick shell and are not barrel-shaped, which helps differentiate them from Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale:  The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, significantly different in appearance from the barrel-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that is often found intracellularly within neutrophils. It is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections, including infections of the Bartholin glands. The typical presentation includes swelling and pus discharge, which is consistent with the given clinical scenario.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is characterized by its kidney or bean shape and lack of a capsule, unlike Neisseria meningitidis, which is capsulated. It is known for causing sexually transmitted infections, including those affecting the genital tract, such as Bartholin gland abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Although Chlamydia can cause genital infections, it is not a Gram-negative diplococcus. Instead, it is an obligate intracellular bacterium with a unique developmental cycle.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid is a Gram-negative bacillus and not a diplococcus.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete, which is not a Gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can mimic erythroblastosis fetalis due to its ability to infect erythroid progenitor cells and inhibit erythropoiesis, leading to severe anemia. Erythroblastosis fetalis typically results from maternal antibodies targeting fetal red blood cells, causing hemolysis and severe anemia; Parvovirus B19 causes a similar effect through a direct infection of the erythroid cells.

 

Parvovirus B19 is associated with:

 

  1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  2. Transient aplastic crisis
  3. Pure red cell aplasia
  4. Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)

 

Erythema infectiosum rash :

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): Incorrect, as HSV does not typically cause the hematologic manifestations associated with erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Incorrect, while EBV can cause hematological disturbances, it does not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis but is more associated with conditions like infectious mononucleosis.

 

Option C. Picornavirus: Incorrect, this group of viruses, which includes enteroviruses and rhinoviruses, does not produce hematological symptoms that mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can uniquely mimic erythroblastosis fetalis by causing severe fetal anemia and related complications through its direct impact on erythroid progenitor cells. Awareness of this potential complication is essential, particularly in pregnant women, as the infection can lead to significant fetal outcomes, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mono-nucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibody test

 

  • Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody reaction test and is used in glandular fever like Infectious mononucleosis.
  • Heterophile antibodies have the ability to agglutinate RBCs of different animal species.
  • Paul Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes for agglutination and Monospot test uses horse erythrocytes for agglutination.
  • In Infectious Mononucleosis, IgM heterophile antibodies are detectable for the first 3 months of infection and they can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Complement mediated cell damage: This refers to a different mechanism where the complement system causes lysis of cells. It is not related to the principle of the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Precipitation reaction uses a soluble antigen to form a precipitate in a solid media when combined with an antibody.

 

Option D. Neutralisation reaction: Neutralization reactions involve antibodies that neutralize the pathogen, preventing it from infecting cells. This principle does not apply to the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody test used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis. It detects IgM heterophile antibodies that can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, which are present during the early stages of the infection.

choices.text: Aspiration is an important mode of transmission
Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis
Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Legionella pneumonia is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis

 

Explanation:

 

Legionella pneumonia, caused by Legionella pneumophila, is diagnosed using a variety of methods. The urinary antigen test is a rapid, sensitive, and specific method for diagnosing Legionella infections, especially for Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1. While culture remains the definitive method, the urinary antigen test is often considered the gold standard in clinical settings 

Comparison of Diseases Caused by Legionella pneumophila

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspiration is an important mode of transmission: This is incorrect. While aspiration can be a mode of transmission, inhalation of contaminated water droplets is more common.

 

Option C. Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever: This is incorrect. Legionnaires' disease and Pontiac fever are two distinct forms of legionellosis. Legionnaires' disease is a severe form of pneumonia with systemic symptoms, while Pontiac fever is a milder, self-limiting, flu-like illness without pneumonia.

 

Option D. High person-to-person transmission: This is incorrect. Legionella does not typically spread from person to person. The primary mode of transmission is through the inhalation or aspiration of contaminated water droplets.

 

Educational objective:

 

The urinary antigen test is a crucial diagnostic tool for Legionella pneumonia, providing a rapid and specific method for detecting Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1.
